body: IT is part of the American canon, a story that has survived the swiftly changing currents of political fashion and academic revisionism. On Christmas Day in 1776, a ragged, suffering band of soldiers crossed the icy Delaware River from Pennsylvania into New Jersey and surprised an enemy garrison in Trenton. It was but a small skirmish, but it looms
geo_facet: CROSSROADS OF THE AMERICAN REVOLUTION NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA (NJ)
title: Reclaiming the Revolution

body: A plan by the City Sanitation Department to build a trash-transfer station at the site of a former incinerator on the Bensonhurst waterfront was denounced yesterday by Assemblyman William Colton, the chairman of the State Legislative Commission on Solid Waste Management. At a news conference, Mr. Colton presented an analysis of nine sediment
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Trash Station Plan Is Criticized

body: Get some prima donna on the bench, and a day in court can still start the way they portray it on television: a grand pronouncement, the honorable such-and-such presiding, all rise and come to order, the gallery standing in unpracticed reverence as for some joyless Easter Mass. Here is a man who would not take it anymore: Justice James G. Starkey
title: In 3 Decades on Bench, Justice Does Not Pause for Theatrics

body: UNCHECKED for decades, decay has left Coney Island a motley jumble of vacant lots, forbidding bodegas and shabby, if lovable, amusements. But change is on its way to this scruffy slice of south Brooklyn seafront; the signs are everywhere. KeySpan Park, a handsome minor league baseball stadium, has drawn steady crowds since it opened in 2001.
title: LIVING IN/Coney Island, Brooklyn; Safety Belts On? Renewal Has Its Hazards

body: Nabila Nazli was standing at a window, dangling her newborn above the sidewalk about 20 feet below. Flames were tearing through her second-story apartment in Brooklyn yesterday morning, and she was screaming for help. Two men had raced to her aid, but they could not get into the wood-frame building. Thinking fast, they stretched out a quilt as a
title: Home Afire, Mother Saves 4 and Stays With 5th

body: The builders of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge probably saved someone's life yesterday. They needed a place to dump all the displaced dirt from its construction, and ended up creating a new hunk of land that jutted out of Brooklyn into Coney Island Creek like a hitchhiker's thumb. In 1962, that land became part of a city park. Yesterday, it became an
title: Pilot Stops Short of New Jersey, in Brooklyn Park

body: A Brooklyn mother of two was killed yesterday afternoon while accepting a housewarming gift when her newly estranged husband rushed up and shot her with a shotgun he had hidden up his sleeve, the police and witnesses said. He then reloaded and shot himself to death. The woman, identified by friends as Karen Skellas, 44, an administrative worker at
title: Man Kills Estranged Wife, Then Himself, at Her Door

body: FOR most people who grew up in and around Sheepshead Bay, the allure of Plum Beach, a rest stop off the Belt Parkway on Brooklyn's southern shore, has been unchanging for as long as they can remember. The quiet, barren area is secluded, making it a convenient spot for assignations of various sorts. Decades ago, the beach's parking lot was notorious
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Deadly Days At a Lovers' Lane

body: One man was killed and another wounded in a knife fight last night, the police said. The man who died, identified by the police as Devonne Dover, 29, was stabbed in the neck and chest around 6:30 p.m. in front of his building at 22 Hubbard Place in Gravesend. He was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead on arrival. The
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Dies In Knife Fight

body: City and state officials are celebrating their commitment to fill space in the Freedom Tower. But there seems to be less cheering -- and considerable distress -- among people who might actually have to report for work every day in the symbolic replacement for the destroyed World Trade Center. Employees of state and federal agencies that may be
title: Employees Say No to Working in Freedom Tower

body: Two years ago, when a long-awaited wrecking crew finally tore down the 200-foot smokestacks of the shuttered Southwest Brooklyn Incinerator, residents and elected officials in Bensonhurst were there to celebrate. They even had gold-painted sledgehammers. It was a joyous day for a neighborhood that had fought for more than 40 years to close the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENSONHURST; A Lesson In Civics: The Devil You Know

body: BROOKLYN'S enthusiasts will tell you that the borough is like Paris in its long and distinguished literary tradition. And that consummate enthusiast, Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, has even been known to call it ''the new Left Bank.'' Tomorrow Mr. Markowitz's office has organized what he calls the first-ever Brooklyn Book Festival
title: Literary Voice, Brooklyn Accent

body: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Friday about the rescue of an elderly woman from a fire in her Brooklyn apartment misstated her address and neighborhood. The address is 1935 Shore Parkway, not Belt Parkway, and it is in Gravesend, not Coney Island.
title: Corrections

body: Firefighters rescued an 85-year-old woman from a fire that broke out about 6:40 a.m. yesterday in her apartment in a high-rise building at 1935 Belt Parkway in Coney Island. The firefighters, Brian Pascascio, 24, and Joe Walz, 38, found the woman lying next to her bed and carried her out of the 11th-floor apartment. The woman, whom fire officials
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Firefighters Rescue Woman

body: VITO BUZZETTA, a bricklayer who has lived in Bensonhurst for 33 years, stood in his driveway on a recent afternoon -- hose in one hand, watering can in another -- and gestured toward a six-story apartment building under construction across the street. ''Look what they did,'' he said. ''It's too big.'' Mr. Buzzetta's opinion is a popular one in the
title: LIVING IN/ Bensonhurst, Brooklyn; An Old Neighborhood Grows Up Again

body: BEHIND the tall grass and trees of Calvert Vaux Park in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, hidden from the soccer players on Sundays, is a nautical graveyard. Burned and rotting hulks of abandoned vessels jut from the dirty beach into the silted, sluggish water of Coney Island Creek. The ribs of other ships emerge from the shallows like bones. No one is sure
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENSONHURST; The Ghost Ships of Coney Island Creek

body: Eight men and six companies were charged yesterday with defrauding drivers and gas stations in New York by selling hundreds of thousands of gallons of low-grade gasoline as premium grade, and state prosecutors are seeking to recover $3 million from the operation, court records show. In a 202-count indictment filed in State Supreme Court in
title: In Gas Scheme, Regular Was Sold as Premium, Prosecutors Say

body: Lyle Stuart, a renegade journalist and publisher whose picaresque life included clashes with Walter Winchell, the publication of ''Naked Came the Stranger'' and the decision to print ''The Anarchist Cookbook,'' died on Saturday at Englewood Hospital and Medical Center in Englewood, N.J. He was 83 and lived in Fort Lee, N.J. The cause of death was a
title: Lyle Stuart, Publisher of Renegade Titles, Dies at 83

body: THE multimillion-dollar teardown is generally considered a suburban phenomenon, a peculiar indulgence of the well-heeled in places of grassy splendor, like Greenwich or Great Neck. But there is a quiet, out-of-the-way section of the Gravesend neighborhood in Brooklyn where it has become commonplace for houses to trade for millions of dollars, only
title: Paying Any Price To Live Here

body: IT'S not every day that there are sightings of the Virgin Mary, the Easter Bunny and an overstuffed pink pig sporting a black leather jacket and a strand of rainbow-colored beads. But anyone who walked by 467 11th Street in Park Slope recently would have spotted such a trio. After seven years of festooning their red-brick row house for holidays
title: URBAN STUDIES/Celebrating; Where Every Day Is a Holiday

body: It was a heavily hip-hop extravaganza outside Public School 45 in South Ozone Park, Queens, this month, with even the littlest kindergartners getting funky to tracks like ''You Gotta Believe (Atomic Slyde)'' by Fierce Ruling Diva. On the same morning, at the opposite end of the city, children at P.S. 81 in Riverdale, the Bronx, stepped through less
title: When School Turns Into the Land of 1,000 Dances

body: THE traffic arteries heading out of the city were already clogged with cars as the Jetty Jumpers, a group of ordinary guys with comic-book nicknames, made good their escape from New York. It was wave-running weather on the Brooklyn waterfront, and the surf was up. First came Saze, a carpenter from Coney Island, whose favorite tree had been blowing
title: URBAN STUDIES: Jumping; Their Great Escape

body: Two young men were killed in Brooklyn in 1992. The cases were never solved. There, the obvious similarities end. Boris Roitman, 21, thought to be an informant for the police, was found beside a tennis court in Gravesend, shot in the neck and chest. Thien Diep, 24, a high-stakes pool player who had his own cue, was robbed, his body incinerated in a
title: 14 Years Later, 2 Killings Are Linked to Russian Mob

body: A disembodied voice from Colorado threw the trial of two retired detectives into temporary turmoil yesterday, as the jailed gangster who had once accused them of murder turned about and, their lawyers said, pronounced them innocent of some of the charges. On the day prosecutors planned to rest their case and at the very moment when it seemed the
title: A Phone Call From Prison Roils Trial of Ex-Detectives

body: To the Editor: I have to laugh at Chairman Robert B. Tierney's defense of the Landmarks Preservation Commission. Brooklyn has a few rare Dutch Colonial farmhouses, the city's oldest architectural form, yet nearly half are still not landmarked. In 2003, after the demolition of a 1790's example the city itself had owned, I urged Mr. Tierney to
title: Questionable Decisions About Landmarks

body: Pucker Up Q. I recently came across a mention of a bridge known in the 18th century as the Kissing Bridge, near the present Third Avenue and 77th Street. Tell me more. A. That particular bridge was on or near the old Boston Post Road, and would have then been about four miles north of town. A requirement for a good kissing bridge, as with a lover's
title: F. Y. I.

body: There were two surveillance teams on the streets of southern Brooklyn that day in January, 1992. One was the law: a task force of federal agents and police detectives. The other was the mob: a crew of gangsters who had disguised their sedan with a fake police light and a cardboard cup of coffee on the dashboard. Although they came from opposing
title: A Tale of Cops And Mobsters Who Failed To Overlap
